stream_context.summary: Kaze works on blocking out the geometry and gameplay flow for the first of fifteen overworld areas. The stream focuses heavily on design philosophy, particularly how to create player intrigue, guide the player naturally, and tutorialize mechanics in an engaging way. He also discusses the project's finances, a unique non-deterministic random number generator he created, and progress on other projects.

development_findings.summary: The project has reached a major milestone with all 15 main courses structurally complete. The current development focus has shifted to the overworld, side content, and graphical passes by Biobak.
development_findings.quote: We basically just finished course 15, which means all the main courses are done. Now, all that's remaining is some side levels, Biobak's reworks, and the overworld.

development_findings.summary: Kaze believes the overworld is the most critical component of the game. He is dedicating significant effort to make it intriguing, dynamic, and a core part of the player experience, comparing its interconnected nature to Banjo-Kazooie.
development_findings.quote: I think the overworld is the most important part of the game. So we're putting a lot of care into this.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a custom, highly optimized random number generator that unintentionally relies on the N64's clock cycle counter, making it non-deterministic. This 'true randomness' makes the game impossible to tool-assist speedrun (TAS), a significant technical and community implication he is aware of.
development_findings.quote: I made a new random function that is faster... The problem is that it kind of uses like true noise on accident so it may be impossible to test this game.

development_findings.summary: To tutorialize the game's unique swimming mechanics, Kaze decided against a simple HUD pop-up in favor of a more charming, in-world solution: a friendly Cheep Cheep will appear holding a sign with the controls when the player is in the water.
development_findings.quote: The way I intended to teach swimming controls is maybe just a HUD pop-up... I think literally what we're gonna do is add a cheap, cheap that holds a sign up and the sign is gonna have the controls on it.

development_findings.summary: A wall-kicking tutorial was removed from an early level after playtesting revealed it was not enjoyable, demonstrating an iterative design process where player feedback directly leads to level changes.
development_findings.quote: During playtesting I noticed that it sucks, so I removed it.

development_findings.summary: After struggling with a long dock design meant to frame the view, Kaze pivoted to using a short, non-interactive introductory cutscene. The cutscene will show Mario's boat arriving and pan around to establish key landmarks like the lighthouse, solving the player guidance problem more elegantly.
development_findings.quote: I think a dock like this is much more reasonable actually. This is a nicer view to start off at. So we're going to show everything in the cutscene at first.

development_findings.summary: To gate access to the first course and teach the global coin mechanic, Kaze plans to have a character (Pachyderm) block the entrance, requiring the player to collect a small number of coins from the overworld to pay them off.

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed that the project has a significant financial cost, particularly for paying team members like Biobak for their work. He funds this through his Patreon, YouTube channel, and potential donations, indicating a semi-professional model for this large-scale fan project.
context_findings.quote: The game as a whole is going to cost me in the tens of thousands, just so you guys know. Maybe I will start a donation drive for that or something, I don't know.

context_findings.summary: Kaze positions himself as a developer who deeply values performance and optimization, criticizing modern game development trends and engines like Unreal for being bloated. He takes pride in making his complex game run on original N64 hardware.
context_findings.quote: In a world full of unoptimized piece-of-shit games, this one game runs so well and easily that it can even run on a fucking Nintendo 64. The last game developer alive that cares about performance.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's development philosophy is driven by personal interest. He dismisses the idea of creating a randomizer, despite acknowledging its popularity, because he personally finds them to be a 'hollow' experience without design intent.
context_findings.quote: I do not like developing games that I personally wouldn't enjoy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering the possibility of creating an original, commercial version of the game by removing all Nintendo IP, which would allow for a standalone PC release.
context_findings.quote: There's a consideration to strip this off copyright stuff and, like, put it out as a PC game as well. So, like, everyone can just play it without needing an emulator.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reflects on his growing popularity and how it has changed the way he can interact online, leading him to use unconventional platforms like LinkedIn for casual posting.
context_findings.quote: I recently ran into the issue that my twitter account got so popular that i can't really shitpost on twitter anymore whatever's on my mind so i started to shitpost on linkedin instead.

biobak.summary: Biobak is responsible for graphically reworking all the game's levels. This is a paid role, highlighting a professional relationship within the team and the project's significant budget.
biobak.quote: Yes, Biobak is reworking all the levels and I have to pay him a lot for that.

biobak.summary: Kaze referenced a drawing Biobak had sent him for the overworld, indicating Biobak's contributions extend to concept art and layout ideas.

zeina.summary: Kaze asks Zeina (referred to as 'say now') for a reference image for the 'lead up to Bunny Brushwoods', showing their direct collaboration on level design and art direction during development.
zeina.quote: Say now did you send me the image?

zeina.summary: Kaze shares a personal anecdote about a poster his wife, Zeina, has in their living room, offering a small glimpse into their personal life and dynamic outside of the project.
zeina.quote: Oh my wife has a poster from vinnie vines also spent in our living room and i don't like that post of him... it feels so weird because like you know vinnie is just the guy like online to me.

key_stories.title: The Accidental 'True Random' Generator
key_stories.summary: In his quest for optimization, Kaze created a new random number generator that accidentally became non-deterministic by using unpredictable hardware states. While proud of the technical achievement and performance gain, he is conflicted because it makes the game impossible for the Tool-Assisted Speedrun community to analyze and play.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed a random number generator that was faster than the one in the original Super Mario 64 to improve performance.
key_stories.process: Kaze wrote a new random function that relies on the N64's internal clock cycle counter. He discovered this counter is influenced by minute, unpredictable hardware timings, effectively creating 'true random' behavior. He confirmed this by testing on both an emulator with save states and on real hardware, where outcomes differed on each boot.
key_stories.outcome: The new function is faster but is non-deterministic, meaning the same inputs will produce different outcomes. This makes the game impossible to TAS, a fact Kaze is conflicted about but accepts as a trade-off for performance.
key_stories.key_quote: Literally the movement of electrons is going to affect it which is basically true noise. So but I don't actually like that it's using true noise because I would like the game to be... it's just that doing it this way is more optimized so I kind of have to do it this way.

key_stories.title: Crafting the First Impression
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent a significant portion of the stream redesigning the game's opening area to make it more intriguing. He iteratively worked through several ideas, from adding visual blockers to a long pier, before settling on a plan that uses a short cutscene for exposition and a small coin-collecting task to gate progress, creating a more compelling player introduction.
key_stories.challenge: The initial design for the game's first overworld area was uninspired, allowing the player to walk straight into the first level without any sense of discovery or intrigue.
key_stories.process: Kaze live-streamed his design process, starting with a basic, oversized layout. He experimented with adding visual blockers like dunes, then tried a long dock to frame a view of a distant lighthouse. After identifying the dock's potential for player frustration, he pivoted to using a cinematic cutscene to achieve the same goal. He also decided to use a character, Pachyderm, to block the first course until the player collects a few coins, teaching a core mechanic.
key_stories.outcome: The final plan involves a short introductory cutscene to establish the environment and key landmarks, a gated entrance to the first course that requires collecting a few coins, and environmental tutorials for core mechanics like swimming. This creates a much more engaging and intentional opening experience.
key_stories.key_quote: I think the overworld is the most important part of the game. So we're putting a lot of care into this.

open_questions.context: Kaze stated the project will cost 'tens of thousands' of dollars, that he pays artist Biobak 'a lot', and that he relies on Patreon and sponsors to fund development.

open_questions.context: Kaze revealed that he is considering removing Nintendo's IP from the game to release it as a standalone commercial product on PC.

open_questions.context: Kaze discovered his custom random number generator is non-deterministic, making the game impossible to TAS (Tool-Assisted Speedrun). He seems conflicted about this.

open_questions.context: Kaze and his wife, Zeina, collaborate on the game. He asked her for an art asset during the stream and also shared a personal anecdote about their home life.
